I read elsewhere that Bosch did know and warned VW that they could not use the software (supposedly intended for testing, which doesn't make sense) in cars delivered to customers.

It is totally unbelievable that "only a few people knew about the deception" as Volkswagen's new chief executive, Matthias Mueller claims. Dozens, and perhaps hundreds, must have known about it. Certainly not just the four (4) executives that VW has suspended.

The software code for the fuel injection and emissions control program is not written by 3 or 4 top executives. It is written by a team or teams of programmers. The programmers are given their instructions by supervising engineers. Passing down the chain, those engineers must have given the instructions to develop and incorporate the program which detected a test cycle, and the subroutine which altered the motor's behavior during test cycles.

Since the direct-injection technology, where fuel is fed by a 'common rail' at extremely high pressure (25,000 psi) was developed by Bosch, Bosch must also have known what Volkswagen engineers were doing.

So, first: Volkswagen still isn't coming clean. Volkswagen CEO Matthias Mueller still isn't telling the truth.

Second: we need whistleblower protection, and incentives. If one of the engineers or programmers in the chain of command down to the software teams had made Volkswagen's cheating public, he would have become unemployable for life in German industry. Therefore, a fund should be established to guarantee whistleblowers a lifetime income.

Third, vaunted 'German engineering expertise' will now look terrible if VW can't correct the diesels already sold.

GM at least did this and were baffled at how VW met standards without urea. Bob Lutz has stated this. But their engineers probably tested the emissions using the same process the EPA does and the engine passed. GM finally decided to use the urea tank on the Cruze.

The problem with GM et. al. is that they didn't have the imagination to think VW would use fraud to pass the test, and didn't look for it.

Anyone involved in product development knows to learn from one's competitors' experience.

For competitors may have a far better way to accomplish something that could be incorporated into YOUR product.

If VW had a less expensive way to meet the diesel emissions standards than other car manufacturers, then I expect GM, BMW and Mercedes would:
1. buy a VW diesel and measure its performance.
2. If the VW worked as well as stated, take it apart to determine EXACTLY what VW did.
3. find any related published information (Patent filings, SAE papers) and learn about VW's ability to do meet the standards.
4. Consider buying/licensing VW's technology if it worked.

I suspect these events happened and GM, BMW and Mercedes KNEW VW diesels did not perform as stated.

This is a story the Times should pursue, not that VW could fool the emissions testers, but also that the automobile industry likely investigated VW's claims, found them false, but did not publish the findings.

The story may go far deeper than a few people at VW.

Good insight and good argumentation for China’s security bureau. Everybody needs a job. The problem is personal. When one gets arrested for protesting or seeking redress to an injustice you are alone against a powerful security apparatus. That is why protesters in China need help. Individuals are not protected when their property, family member, or friend gets confiscated or arrested they have little hope. Especially now, since all the rights lawyers have been arrested.

It’s possible to have a bit of sympathy for China’s security force. Of course there is injustice everywhere on earth. People who suffer from injustice, feeling desperate and helpless are primed for radicalization and violence. Best to provide them a way to vent frustration and redress the injustice, if possible.

But human beings are prone to complain. They are gullible to rumors. They rubber neck at oddities and accidents. So there is a need to control the complaint channels, these days it includes internet access. A crowd of netizens will gather around a hot issue in lightning speed. The potential to erupt into physical trouble is high. Remember Arab Springs? Western thinking will protest. They have a Holy Cow named freedom of expression, another Cow is the freedom of gathering to demonstrate in public.

An unruly crowd is dangerous, easily get out of hand. There is no reason why it is a given right. Last Saturday in usually peaceful Toronto a confrontation between a rowdy party crowd and the police broke out at the annual art festival Nuit Blanche. The police was outnumbered by the riotous mob. Several officers were injured. China’s security police faces similar hazard, but many times more dangerous because their crowds are so much larger. They learned to constantly send a signal that they have the upper hand and will nip the bud of trouble at the earliest sign. Draconian? Sure. But it is better than mayhem.

The phrase "to bear arms" itself has a long history, back through the earliest origins of English, centuries before guns even existed, and until (at best) the early 20th C had nothing to do with personal gun ownership. "Arms" referred to any of the equipment for making war, and to "bear arms" meant a) to carry such equipment in the national defense, and/or b) to be a member of the officer class in the monarch's service (i.e., to be somewhere on the ladder of aristocracy in the feudal-aristocratic system). To secure the right to "bear arms" for all (male) citizens was an important statement about the organization of the new, republican form of government. It had NOTHING to do with personally owning a gun. At the time, in a largely agrarian society, guns were a common tool; one would no more enshrine the right to own one in the founding document of the nation than one would enshrine the right to own a shovel. That an agenda-driven court has decided otherwise changes the law, but it doesn't change the fact. No one would read that phrase that way in that period in any other context--it's as bad a one-off decision as Bush v Gore, and at least as pernicious. Hypocritical too, since the same justices who wanted that outcome were committed to something they pretend to call "originalism," so they had to make up a fraudulent reading of the phrase to adhere to that (equally misguided) doctrine.
I don't think it is quite right that nobody is talking about repealing the Second Amendment and confiscating guns.
